newsitem.title: PERU: Fujimori taking political advantage of raid - poll.
newsitem.headline: Fujimori taking political advantage of raid - poll.

text.p: More Peruvians believe President Alberto Fujimori ordered the military storming of the Japanese ambassador's residence out of concern for his political future than for the good of the country, a new poll showed on Wednesday.
Some 64.5 percent also said the government has exploited the attack to score political points, while only 29.3 percent disagreed, according to a survey of 400 Lima residents by local pollster Imasen.

The poll said 46.8 percent believed Fujimori ordered the deadly April 22 storming of Marxist hostage-takers due to "concern about his political future," while 27.5 percent said the motive was "what was necessary for the country."
The government said it was forced to strike against the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) after four months of negotiations had failed to solve the crisis peacefully.
Authorities have moved swiftly to deny reports that two rebels were executed during the operation and some of the guerrillas' bodies withheld from families and buried secretly.

While politicians and pro-government media have routinely referred to just "three victims" of the operation -- referring to the one captive and two soldiers who died -- 82 percent of those surveyed expressed sympathy for "all the deaths," including the 14 slain guerrillas.
The government has also tried to use the raid to distract attention from allegations of torture, murder and intimidation by intelligence services, according to 63 percent of those polled.
The survey, carried out on April 26 and 27, had a 5 percent margin of error.
Fujimori, whose personal popularity has soared with the end of the hostage crisis, is mulling a third election bid in 2000.
